newsitem.title: USA: IPO HIGHLIGHTS - New issues spring higher.
newsitem.headline: IPO HIGHLIGHTS - New issues spring higher.

text.p: Shares of new issues got a warm reception on Wall Street on Wednesday, with five new offerings all reaping solid gains at their market debuts.
Companies going public today in U.S. markets:
-- Corsair Communications Inc jumped over 30 percent, gaining 4-3/4 to 19-3/4 after its $37.5 million initial public offering.
The Palo Alto, Calif., company sold 2.5 million shares for $15 each, above its range of $14 to $15. It makes a system that delivers multiple products and services to the wireless phone industry.

-- Vestcom International Inc also rose, adding 21 percent, up 2-3/4 to 15-3/4. Shares were priced at $13, the top of a range of $11 to $13. The Lyndhurst, N.J. company provides computer output and document management services.
Oppenheimer was the lead underwriter of the 3.85 million share offering, which raised roughly $50 million. Nearly 2.5 million shares had changed hands in late trading.
-- Information Management Associates Inc had textbook IPO gains of about 11 percent, with the stock up 1-1/2 to 14-1/2. A total of 3.9 million shares were sold, with 2.8 million by the company.
Information Management, based in Shelton, Conn., makes a prepackaged software used by telephone call centers.

Corsair had been expected to soar but the success of Information Management Associates and Vestcom was better than some IPO analysts had predicted. Aside from those three technology companies, two foreign companies made their market debuts on the New York Stock Exchange:

-- China Southern Airlines Co Ltd was one of the most heavily traded stocks on the NYSE on its first day of trading. The stock was at 31-13/16. More than 2.8 million shares had traded with more than an hour left in the session.

China Southern operates 270 routes serving 68 destinations in China. It has said it will use proceeds from the offering to buy new aircraft, repay debt, and install and expand flight operation systems and facilities.
-- Brazilian state-owned electric company Companhia Paranaense de Energia (Copel) rose 1-1/8 to 19-1/8 in heavy trading. It offered American Depositary Shares (ADSs) for $18 each.
